unnormalised: Planning a trip by Indian Railways? It's practically a rite of passage for anyone exploring India, from backpacking foreigners to desi families heading home for Diwali. But navigating the system can feel like a puzzle, especially with all the abbreviations and codes. Let’s break it down, shall we?
normalised: Planning a trip by Indian Railways? It's practically a rite of passage for anyone exploring India, from backpacking foreigners to desi families heading home for Diwali. But navigating the system can feel like a puzzle, especially with all the abbreviations and codes. Let’s break it down, shall we?

unnormalised: First things first, you’ll need to book your ticket. IRCTC is your go-to website or app. You’ll see trains like the “12002 Bhopal Shatabdi Express” or the “12863 Howrah Yesvantpur Express”. Notice the 5-digit number? That’s the train number, and it’s how you’ll identify your train on the platform screens. Booking windows usually open 120 days in advance, so plan ahead. Getting a confirmed ticket, especially during peak seasons like summer vacations or Durga Puja, is an art form! Try for Tatkal tickets or keep an eye on the waitlist.
normalised: First things first, you’ll need to book your ticket. I-R-C-T-C is your go-to website or app. You’ll see trains like the “twelve thousand and two Bhopal Shatabdi Express” or the “twelve thousand eight hundred and sixty three Howrah Yesvantpur Express”. Notice the five-digit number? That’s the train number, and it’s how you’ll identify your train on the platform screens. Booking windows usually open one hundred and twenty days in advance, so plan ahead. Getting a confirmed ticket, especially during peak seasons like summer vacations or Durga Puja, is an art form! Try for Tatkal tickets or keep an eye on the waitlist.

unnormalised: Now, let's talk about classes. You’ll see options like 1A (First Class AC), 2A (Second Class AC), 3A (Third Class AC), SL (Sleeper Class), and even CC (AC Chair Car) for daytime journeys. 3A is a good sweet spot for comfort and cost, offering AC and berths. SL is the classic Indian train experience - open windows, the smell of chai wafting through, and a chance to chat with fellow travelers. Just be prepared for a bit of hustle and bustle!
normalised: Now, let's talk about classes. You’ll see options like one A (First Class A C), two A (Second Class A C), three A (Third Class A C), S L (Sleeper Class), and even C C (A C Chair Car) for daytime journeys. three A is a good sweet spot for comfort and cost, offering A C and berths. S L is the classic Indian train experience - open windows, the smell of chai wafting through, and a chance to chat with fellow travelers. Just be prepared for a bit of hustle and bustle!

unnormalised: Once you have your ticket, PNR status is your best friend. That’s your Passenger Name Record, a 10-digit number that tells you the real-time status of your ticket – whether it’s confirmed, waitlisted, or RAC (Reservation Against Cancellation). You can check it on the IRCTC website or through numerous apps. Keep an eye on it, especially if you’re on the waiting list. A WL 5/6 ticket means you are 6th on the waiting list for WL 5.
normalised: Once you have your ticket, P-N-R status is your best friend. That’s your Passenger Name Record, a ten-digit number that tells you the real-time status of your ticket – whether it’s confirmed, waitlisted, or R-A-C (Reservation Against Cancellation). You can check it on the I-R-C-T-C website or through numerous apps. Keep an eye on it, especially if you’re on the waiting list. A W-L five divided by six ticket means you are sixth on the waiting list for W-L five.

unnormalised: Platforms can be chaotic, especially in big stations like Delhi Junction or Mumbai CST. Arrive at least 30 mins before departure to find your platform. Platform numbers can change at the last minute, so listen for announcements or check the display boards. And remember those train numbers we talked about? That's how you find your train.
normalised: Platforms can be chaotic, especially in big stations like Delhi Junction or Mumbai C-S-T. Arrive at least thirty minutes before departure to find your platform. Platform numbers can change at the last minute, so listen for announcements or check the display boards. And remember those train numbers we talked about? That's how you find your train.

unnormalised: Finally, remember to carry your ID proof – Aadhaar card, PAN card, or any other government-issued ID is a must. And don’t forget the snacks! Train journeys are incomplete without a good supply of chips, biscuits, and of course, chai. Happy travels on the Indian Railways! Just pre-pone all the things by 1 hour because trains can be late.
